paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:** Become familiar using the SparkNLP library to perform relationship extraction
**File locations:** 'spark-labs/rel_extract_big.txt'
**Successful outcome:** Extracted a list of CEO’s and the organization they run using NLP.
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** NLP, NLP Libraries

---

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the dataset and store it in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh

rm -f rel_extract_big.txt
wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/sci-241/rel_extract/rel_extract_big.txt
hdfs dfs -rm spark-labs/rel_extract_big.txt
hdfs dfs -put rel_extract_big.txt spark-labs/

paragraphs.title: Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import trim
from pyspark.ml import Pipeline
from sparknlp.annotator import *
from sparknlp.common import *
from sparknlp.base import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import explode, monotonically_increasing_id
from pyspark.sql.functions import posexplode, array_contains, concat_ws
from pyspark.sql.functions import regexp_extract

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load the data
2 - Inspect the data

paragraphs.text:
%md
As you can see from the above steps, several rows of our DataFrame don’t contain sentences:
* Remove any lines that are empty or start with ‘=’
* Rename the column of data from ‘value’ to ‘text’

Run the code below to clean the data
~~~
cleaned = data.filter((trim(data.value) != "") & (trim(data.value).startswith("=") == False) & (trim(data.value).startswith("--") == False) )
cleaned = cleaned.withColumnRenamed("value", "text")
~~~

paragraphs.title: 3 - Clean the Data

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next we are going to break the documents into sentences using a SparkNLP pipeline composed of 
* a documentAssembler, 
* a sentenceDetector and 
* a finisher.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create the document assembler to convert the text into a form ready to be used by SparkNLP
5 - Create the sentenceDetector
6 - Create the finisher object that will output an array of strings
7 - Create the sentence detector pipeline
8 - Train and run the model to split the documents
9 - Inspect the sentences

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next we are going to 
* get each sentence into its own row,
* rename the 'col' column to 'text'
* add a unique index and then 
* filter those that contain 'CEO' for further processing.

~~~
sents_df = sentences.select(explode('finished_sentence'))
sents_df = sents_df.withColumnRenamed('col','text')

sents_df = sents_df.withColumn('id',monotonically_increasing_id())
sents_to_process = sents_df.filter(sents_df.text.like("%CEO%"))
~~~

paragraphs.title: 10 - Transform the Sentences into Their Own Rows and filter those that contain 'CEO'

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next we are going to build a new SparkNLP pipeline to perform entity recognition.
It will build on the previous one and add the following stages:
* a tokenizer,
* a tagger,
* a converter and
* a ner finisher.

~~~
tokenizer = Tokenizer().setInputCols(["document"]).setOutputCol("token")
ner_tagger = NerDLModel().pretrained().setInputCols(["sentence", "token"]).setOutputCol("ner")
converter = NerConverter().setInputCols(["document", "token", "ner"]).setOutputCol("ner_span")
ner_finisher = Finisher().setInputCols(["ner_span"]).setIncludeMetadata(True).setOutputAsArray(True)
~~~

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create the tokenizer
12 - Create the Named Entity Recognition object from a pretrained model

paragraphs.text:
%md
The format of the nerTagger is hard to use, so include another step in the pipeline to convert it to something more usable

paragraphs.title: 13 - Create the converter
14 - Make a finisher object to get the entities in an array
15 - Build the new pipeline
16 - Perform Entity Recognition
17 - Inspect results

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next we are going to build pairs of persons and organizations.

paragraphs.title: 18 - Create a dataframe containing the entities and their positions in the sentences
19 - Create a dataframe containing the type of entities and their positions in the sentences
20 - Join the two previous dataframes on sentence id and position
21 - Create a dataframe containing only the people from the previous one
22 - Create a dataframe containing only the organizations from the previous one
23 - Join the two previous dataframes and the result of the Entity Recognition on sentence id

paragraphs.text:
%md
Extract the pairs of organizations and people that appear in the pattern
“'ORGANIZATION' CEO 'PERSON'”

paragraphs.title: 24 - Extract the Pairs
25 - Count the pairs of organizations and persons
26 - Filter out those for which count equals 1
Bonus
paragraphs.text:
%md
If time remains, use the pairs you found to look for new patterns.
1. Build patterns out of each pair
2. Get the patterns as Python list as PySpark doesn’t currently support using patterns from columns
3. Find the text in the sentences that matches the two patterns
4. Merge the patterns together
5. Use the most common patterns

%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have now extracted a list of CEO’s and the corporations they are associated with using SparkNLP.

---

%pyspark

cleaned = data.filter((trim(data.value) != "") & (trim(data.value).startswith("=") == False) & (trim(data.value).startswith("--") == False) )
cleaned = cleaned.withColumnRenamed("value", "text")

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create the document assembler to convert the text into a form ready to be used by SparkNLP
5 - Create the sentenceDetector
6 - Create the finisher object that will output an array of strings
7 - Create the sentence detector pipeline
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
sentence_pipe = Pipeline(
    stages = [
    documentAssembler,
    sentenceDetector,
    finisher
  ])

paragraphs.title: 8 - Train and run the model to split the documents
9 - Inspect the sentences

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 10 - Transform the Sentences into Their Own Rows and filter those that contain 'CEO'
11 - Create the tokenizer
12 - Create the Named Entity Recognition object from a pretrained model
13 - Create the converter
14 - Make a finisher object to get the entities in an array
15 - Build the new pipeline
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
ner_pipeline = Pipeline(
    stages = [
    documentAssembler,
    sentenceDetector,
    tokenizer,
    ner_tagger,
    converter,
    ner_finisher
  ])

paragraphs.title: Bonus #1 - Build patterns out of each pair

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Bonus #2 - Get the patterns as Python list
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

pattern1_list = patterns.select('pattern1').rdd.map(lambda x: x['pattern1']).collect()
pattern2_list = patterns.select('pattern2').rdd.map(lambda x: x['pattern2']).collect()

paragraphs.title: Bonus #3 - Find the text in the sentences that matches the two patterns
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

patterns_found = []
for pattern in pattern1_list:
    temp_patterns = sents_df.withColumn("pattern", regexp_extract("text",pattern,1))
    patterns_found.append(temp_patterns.filter(trim(temp_patterns.pattern) != ""))

for pattern in pattern2_list:
    temp_patterns = sents_df.withColumn("pattern", regexp_extract("text",pattern,1))
    patterns_found.append(temp_patterns.filter(trim(temp_patterns.pattern) != ""))

paragraphs.title: Bonus #4 - Merge the patterns together
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

patterns = patterns_found[0]
for i in range(1,len(patterns_found)):
    patterns = patterns.union(patterns_found[i])

paragraphs.title: Bonus #5 - Use the most common patterns

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
